attributes.name: Thyme
attributes.description: Thyme is a perennial evergreen herb in the Lamiaceae (Mint) family. It is related to Oregano. Thyme is cold-hardy to -28.8 Â°C and a perennial in US Hardiness zones 5-8. Thyme can live for 5-6 years but needs to be divided or replaced after 3-4 years. It can be used fresh or dried to season dishes.
attributes.sowing_method: Transplant cuttings or seedlings or direct seed indoors

attributes.name: Lacinato Kale
attributes.description: Lacinato, Dinosaur, Tuscan, or Italian Kale has very dark green or blue-green leaves that are heavily crinkled or blistered (savoyed) instead of curled. The leaves have a rich, tender taste and are softer than curly green kales. Can be harvested at baby or adult stage. Delicious raw or cooked. Light frosts increase the sweetness of the leaves.
attributes.sowing_method: Direct seed outdoors or transplant seedlings

attributes.name: Red Pointed Cabbage
attributes.description: Pointed red cabbage is a type of red cabbage with a pointed head. It's leaves have a softer texture and sweeter taste and are more open than typical cabbage. It can be added to stir-fries and casseroles, boiled, sautÃ©ed, or fermented into sauerkraut.
attributes.sowing_method: Direct seed indoors (and transplant seedlings after hardening off) or outdoors

attributes.name: Rose
attributes.description: Roses are flowering woody perennials in the Rosa genus and Rosaceae family. There are over 100 species, most of which are native to Asia, and 1000s of cultivars, which can take the shape of shrubs or climbing plants with sickle-shaped prickles or thorns. Their flowers, which are also known as roses, are large, showy, and fragrant. Roses produce berry-like fruit which are known as rose hips. Domestic cultivars often do not produce fruit because their flowers are so tightly petalled that they cannot be pollinated. The rose hips of the Dog Rose and Rugosa Rose are very high in Vitamin C. Roses are generally propagated through cuttings. If starting from seed, stratify seeds to improve germination. More growing information is available in individual Rose species entries.
